headline: Should HSBC’s Upgrade and Predictive Betting Platform Partnership Prompt Action From Flutter (FLUT) Investors?
summary: In recent days, HSBC upgraded Flutter Entertainment from Hold to Buy and the company announced the late-2025 launch of a predictive sports betting platform in partnership with CME Group, as well as a change in voting rights involving Parvus Asset Management acquiring over 5% of voting rights. This series of announcements has drawn wider attention to Flutter's sector leadership and highlighted differing views among analysts about the company’s future prospects. We'll explore how Flutter's...

headline: Commodity Futures Trading Stopped After Data Center Glitch
summary: “Due to a cooling issue at CyrusOne data centers, our markets are currently halted,” the spokesperson said in an emailed statement.  Other platforms including EBS, used in foreign exchange, were impacted by the halt.  Core exchanges operated by CME include the Chicago Board of Trade, the New York Mercantile Exchange and the Commodity Exchange.

Core exchanges operated by CME include the Chicago Board of Trade, the New York Mercantile Exchange and the Commodity Exchange.

headline: Oil in Worst Monthly Run Since 2023 as Glitch Halts US Futures
summary: Live trading of commodities futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange has halted due to technical issues, according to a notice on the CME Group website.  Nymex is part of the CME Group.  OPEC+ nations meet virtually on Sunday and will probably stick with a plan to pause output increases in early 2026, delegates said.

headline: CME Outage Causes Thin Liquidity in Forex, Bonds. Trade Could Be Choppy.
summary: Currencies and bonds are trading but liquidity is thin after trading of futures and options on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange was halted due to a data-center problem.  The situation is exacerbated by low liquidity following Thursday's U.S. Thanksgiving holiday.  On currency markets, analysts also reported that forex trading on the EBS platform—a wholesale electronic trading platform for foreign exchange that is part of CME Group—was affected by the outage.

content.title: CME Outage Causes Thin Liquidity in Forex, Bonds. Trade Could Be Choppy.
content.summary: Currencies and bonds are trading but liquidity is thin after trading of futures and options on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange was halted due to a data-center problem.  The situation is exacerbated by low liquidity following Thursday's U.S. Thanksgiving holiday.  On currency markets, analysts also reported that forex trading on the EBS platform—a wholesale electronic trading platform for foreign exchange that is part of CME Group—was affected by the outage.

headline: Stock Futures, Gold, Oil Trading Halted By  Data Center Issue on Black Friday
summary: Investors looking to gauge sentiment ahead of the resumption of normal stock market activity after Thanksgiving were experiencing issues on Friday with trading halted in U.S. index futures and other contracts.  Technical issues have disrupted CME Group, the exchange that hosts trading in futures tracking the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq-100.  “Due to a cooling issue at CyrusOne data centers, our markets are currently halted,” CME Group said in a brief statement on its website.

content.title: Stock Futures, Gold, Oil Trading Halted By  Data Center Issue on Black Friday
content.summary: Investors looking to gauge sentiment ahead of the resumption of normal stock market activity after Thanksgiving were experiencing issues on Friday with trading halted in U.S. index futures and other contracts.  Technical issues have disrupted CME Group, the exchange that hosts trading in futures tracking the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq-100.  “Due to a cooling issue at CyrusOne data centers, our markets are currently halted,” CME Group said in a brief statement on its website.

headline: Stocks Drift in Europe and Asia
summary: Stocks wobbled in Europe on Friday as global trading struggled for direction after the closure of U.S. markets for Thanksgiving, while in Asia trading was mixed to finish the week.  Trading in Europe has been muted with the closure of U.S. markets for Thanksgiving, though activity in New York will resume on Friday, albeit in shortened hours.  In the meantime, a trading halt in U.S. index futures due to a technical issue at the CME Group exchange was doing little to help investors gauge global sentiment.

In the meantime, a trading halt in U.S. index futures due to a technical issue at the CME Group exchange was doing little to help investors gauge global sentiment.

headline: CME Futures Outage Disrupts Trading Across Global Markets
summary: The malfunction was caused by cooling system problems at a data center in the Chicago area, according to facility operator CyrusOne.  The halt is already longer than a similar, hours-long outage due to a technical error back in 2019 and underscores the reach of CME Group Inc. and its Globex electronic trading platform.

headline: Stock Markets Could Cap Best Thanksgiving Week Since 2012
summary: It will take a significant reversal in the recent trend during shortened trading on Black Friday for the stock market to fail to close out a great week.  While it has been a tough November for stocks—the S&P 500’s worst month since April—amid concerns around interest rates and the possibility that tech stocks are in an artificial intelligence (AI) bubble, this was a historic week.  Up around 3.5% since Monday, the S&P 500 is on track for its best performance in a Thanksgiving week since 2012.

content.title: Stock Markets Could Cap Best Thanksgiving Week Since 2012
content.summary: It will take a significant reversal in the recent trend during shortened trading on Black Friday for the stock market to fail to close out a great week.  While it has been a tough November for stocks—the S&P 500’s worst month since April—amid concerns around interest rates and the possibility that tech stocks are in an artificial intelligence (AI) bubble, this was a historic week.  Up around 3.5% since Monday, the S&P 500 is on track for its best performance in a Thanksgiving week since 2012.

headline: Tech Outage Halts Trading in U.S. Stock Futures, Other Key Markets
summary: Trading of futures and options on exchanges operated by CME Group has been halted for hours, disrupting some of the world’s most liquid futures markets for U.S. stocks, Treasurys, commodities such as oil, and other financial instruments.  The glitch kept traders of commodities such as crude oil, gold and palm oil in limbo with prices frozen, raising concerns that market volatility would intensify when the systems were brought back up.  U.S. markets were closed on Thursday for Thanksgiving, raising the importance of futures trading in Asia and Europe in providing a signal on how equities and other asset classes would move in North America when the U.S. reopens for a shortened session Friday.

U.S. markets were closed on Thursday for Thanksgiving, raising the importance of futures trading in Asia and Europe in providing a signal on how equities and other asset classes would move in North America when the U.S. reopens for a shortened session Friday.

headline: CME Partially Restores Operations as Forex Platform Restarts
summary: The halt has gone on longer than a similar outage due to a technical error back in 2019 and underscores the reach of CME Group and its Globex electronic trading platform.  It triggered widespread frustration as market participants contemplated the prospect of a lost trading session for millions of contracts tracking the S&P 500, Dow Jones Industrial Average and Nasdaq 100 on one of the world’s largest derivatives exchanges.  The trading halt was caused by a cooling system malfunction at a data center in the Chicago area, according to facility operator CyrusOne.

The trading halt was caused by a cooling system malfunction at a data center in the Chicago area, according to facility operator CyrusOne.

headline: November stock moves, CME outage, bitcoin above $92K: 3 Things
summary: US stock futures (ES=F, NQ=F, YM=F) are slightly higher on November's final trading day. The stock market will close early today at 1 P.M. CME Group (CME) has restored stock futures operations after an outage disrupted and halted live trading around the world. Bitcoin (BTC-USD) has bounced back above $92,000, putting the cryptocurrency on track for its worst trading month since February. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.

content.title: November stock moves, CME outage, bitcoin above $92K: 3 Things
content.description:
US stock futures (ES=F, NQ=F, YM=F) are slightly higher on November's final trading day. The stock market will close early today at 1 P.M.

CME Group (CME) has restored stock futures operations after an outage disrupted and halted live trading around the world.

Bitcoin (BTC-USD) has bounced back above $92,000, putting the cryptocurrency on track for its worst trading month since February.

To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.

headline: CME Restarts Most Operations After Hours-Long Outage
summary: The exchange’s Globex Futures & Options markets, which handles futures, options, and commodities trading and accounts for 90% of CME Group’s volume, opened at 8:30 a.m. New York time, with trades reported in US futures and options.  The halt had gone on longer than a similar outage due to a technical error back in 2019 and underscores the reach of CME Group and its Globex electronic trading platform.

content.summary: The exchange’s Globex Futures & Options markets, which handles futures, options, and commodities trading and accounts for 90% of CME Group’s volume, opened at 8:30 a.m. New York time, with trades reported in US futures and options.  The halt had gone on longer than a similar outage due to a technical error back in 2019 and underscores the reach of CME Group and its Globex electronic trading platform.

headline: Oil Set for Fourth Monthly Drop on Glut Outlook as WTI Resumes
summary: Brent steadied above $63 a barrel, after a modest advance on Thursday, as an outage on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange caused disruptions to markets across equities, foreign exchange, bonds and commodities.  OPEC+ nations meet virtually on Sunday and will probably stick with a plan to pause output increases in early 2026, delegates said.  Brent oil has fallen 15% this year, with prices hurt by expectations for a global glut after OPEC+ restarted capacity, while drillers outside the alliance also added supplies.

content.summary: Brent steadied above $63 a barrel, after a modest advance on Thursday, as an outage on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange caused disruptions to markets across equities, foreign exchange, bonds and commodities.  OPEC+ nations meet virtually on Sunday and will probably stick with a plan to pause output increases in early 2026, delegates said.  Brent oil has fallen 15% this year, with prices hurt by expectations for a global glut after OPEC+ restarted capacity, while drillers outside the alliance also added supplies.

headline: CME to Reopen Futures, Options Trading After Halt Caused by Data-Center Issue
summary: CME Group said it would reopen futures and options trading after an hourslong glitch at a data center prompted it to halt exchanges across asset classes.  The exchange operator said Friday that its CME Globex Futures & Options markets would open as of 0830 ET.  The move follows earlier restorations of fixed-income and foreign-exchange platforms.

content.title: CME to Reopen Futures, Options Trading After Halt Caused by Data-Center Issue
content.summary: CME Group said it would reopen futures and options trading after an hourslong glitch at a data center prompted it to halt exchanges across asset classes.  The exchange operator said Friday that its CME Globex Futures & Options markets would open as of 0830 ET.  The move follows earlier restorations of fixed-income and foreign-exchange platforms.

headline: CME outage, Jefferies scrutiny, Puma takeover report
summary: Morning Brief host Julie Hyman tracks several of the day's top trending stock tickers. CME Group's (CME) Chicago Mercantile Exchange suffered a data outage Friday morning, disrupting futures trading. Jefferies (JEF) is in focus after the FT reported the company facing scrutiny from regulators over its First Brands ties. Puma (PUM.DE, PUMSY) shares are on the move following a Bloomberg report that China’s Anta Sports is exploring a takeover bid of the sporting goods company. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.

Puma (PUM.DE, PUMSY) shares are on the move following a Bloomberg report that China’s Anta Sports is exploring a takeover bid of the sporting goods company.

headline: CME Group Shares Steady After Hours-Long Trading Outage
summary: CME shares moved in a narrow range, while shares of peers New York Stock Exchange-owner Intercontinental Exchange Inc., Nasdaq Inc. and Cboe Global Markets Inc. nudged higher alongside the broader market.  The exchange’s Globex Futures & Options markets, which handles futures, options, and commodities trading and accounts for 90% of CME Group’s volume, opened at 8:30 a.m. New York time, with trades reported in US futures and options.  Futures and options trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange were frozen for several hours due to a data center fault, leaving market participants unable to trade contracts tracking the S&P 500 and multiple other assets.

headline: Futures and Options Trading Restarts After 10-Hour Outage Hits CME
summary: Exchange operator  CME  Group said trading in futures tied to U.S. stock indexes, Treasurys, crude oil and other major markets had resumed, after being halted for more than 10 hours due to technical problems at a vital data center.  Specialists had scrambled to fix the issue, one of the worst snafus to hit the Chicago-based company in years, which it blamed on difficulties cooling servers at a facility in Illinois.  CME said futures trading resumed as of 8:30 a.m. ET Friday, after earlier restoring some other services, including bond and currency-trading platforms.

content.title: Futures and Options Trading Restarts After 10-Hour Outage Hits CME
content.summary: Exchange operator  CME  Group said trading in futures tied to U.S. stock indexes, Treasurys, crude oil and other major markets had resumed, after being halted for more than 10 hours due to technical problems at a vital data center.  Specialists had scrambled to fix the issue, one of the worst snafus to hit the Chicago-based company in years, which it blamed on difficulties cooling servers at a facility in Illinois.  CME said futures trading resumed as of 8:30 a.m. ET Friday, after earlier restoring some other services, including bond and currency-trading platforms.

headline: Chicago Mercantile Exchange Restarts After Data Center Disruption
summary: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange restored most trading operations after an hours-long outage stemming from problems at a data center. Shares of CME Group (CME) dipped in the premarket session on the news. We're also watching: - Shares of Tilray Brands (TLRY) fell ahead of the US market open after the cannabis company announced that it will implement a one-for-ten reverse stock split of its common stock. - Shares of Oracle (ORCL) declined in early trading after Morgan Stanley warned a gauge of risk on Oracle Corp.'s debt reached a three-year high in November. Lisa Mateo reports.

content.title: Chicago Mercantile Exchange Restarts After Data Center Disruption
content.description:
The Chicago Mercantile Exchange restored most trading operations after an hours-long outage stemming from problems at a data center. Shares of CME Group (CME) dipped in the premarket session on the news. 
We're also watching: 
- Shares of Tilray Brands (TLRY) fell ahead of the US market open after the cannabis company announced that it will implement a one-for-ten reverse stock split of its common stock.
- Shares of Oracle (ORCL) declined in early trading after Morgan Stanley warned a gauge of risk on Oracle Corp.'s debt reached a three-year high in November. 
Lisa Mateo reports.

Shares of CME Group (CME) dipped in the premarket session on the news. Lisa Mateo reports.

headline: Stocks rise in thin Thanksgiving trading

headline: The Private Equity-Owned Data Center Behind CME’s Massive Outage
summary: The Aurora, Illinois, complex has served as the primary hub of digital operations for the world’s largest futures exchange operator CME Group Inc. for nearly two decades.  Traders want to be close to the data center to reduce latency, minimizing the distance data must travel in order to save microseconds.  As a former executive of the data center’s operator once put it: “If you read the book  you can get a real quick lesson on what’s going on.”

content.title: The Private Equity-Owned Data Center Behind CME’s Massive Outage
